title: Analysis of Functions with Eulers and Taylor Poly

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with three columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 2. g prime of x is 64. Column 2. x is 2.1. g prime of x is 41. Column 3. x is 2.2. g prime of x is 20." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>64</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>41</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="y equals g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals g prime of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="g of 2 equals 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are given in the table above. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is three-times differentiable. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with three columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 2. g prime of x is 64. Column 2. x is 2.1. g prime of x is 41. Column 3. x is 2.2. g prime of x is 20." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>64</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>41</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="y equals g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals g prime of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="g of 2 equals 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are given in the table above. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is three-times differentiable. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, 3 x times g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Use a right Riemann sum with the two subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 2 to 2.2, of, g prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(d) It is known that <math alttext="g double prime of x, is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation from part (c) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from 2 to 2.2, of, g prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(e) Use the approximation for <math alttext="the integral from 2 to 2.2, of, g prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> from part (c) to estimate the value of <math alttext="g of 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate <math alttext="g of 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) It is known that <math alttext="g double prime of 2, equals negative 240" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>240</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g triple prime of 2, equals 200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the third-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
